For more than seven years, Republicans have promised they would repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and replace it with something better.   Well, here we are and contrary to all the rhetoric, this plan introduced by my Republican colleagues does not offer solutions to expand coverage, make premiums, co-pays and deductibles more affordable, or improve coverage to care.

The 25 percent cut in Medicaid, a program that provides insurance to one in five Americans, is both heartless and financially unsound. This repeal bill does not lower premiums and out-of-pocket costs, does not expand access to insurance, and is a huge tax cut poorly disguised as a health care bill.

I refuse to support a bill that forces families into health plans with worse coverage and fewer protections. The plan my Republican colleagues have presented to repeal the Affordable Care Act will increase the cost of care for children, disabled, and older adults.

24 million people will be kicked off their health insurance, including 7 million who will lose the insurance they currently have through their employer.   And for the lucky ones who are able to stay insured, coverage will be less available and less affordable for virtually all ages and income groups.

The Republicans #TrumpCare bill will roll back the progress we made under the Affordable Care Act and hurt millions of Americans by increasing the price of insurance and offering less coverage. Americans deserve better than the GOP’s merciless attack on their health care.

This week, Republicans plan to vote on TrumpCare to push 24 million Americans off their health coverage and saddle families across the country with massive health costs.   TrumpCare is an assault on families and is a broken promise to the American people. It will destroy the Medicaid program, increase out-of-pocket costs and allow insurers to charge older Americans five times more than what younger adults pay.

It has been seven years since the Affordable Care Act was implemented. Since then, insurers can no longer deny coverage or raise rates because of pre-existing conditions, hard-working Americans can afford premium health care thanks to generous subsidies, and consumers are protected from the worst abuses of the insurance industry.

#TrumpCare is not the answer to improving coverage for the American people.    The bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act is opposed by Democrats, many Republicans, hospitals, doctors, and patients because it dumps massive health costs on working families and is a broken promise to the American people.

In just seven years since the Affordable Care Act (ACA) went into effect, the law has delivered on the principle goal of covering tens of millions of Americans for whom health insurance was previously out of reach.   Today, 20 million people have health insurance and the percentage of uninsured Americans is at an all-time low. #ACAWorks

TrumpCare will take health insurance away from 24 million people. That’s basically the number of people that live in the state of Texas.   From the crushing age tax forcing older Americans to pay premiums five times higher than young adults to the Medicare cuts that will shorten the life of the program by three years, it is hard to find someone this bill helps.

Later today, the House of Representatives will vote on the Republican #TrumpCare bill that repeals the Affordable Care Act.   I will vote 'no' because this bill is disastrous for working Americans. 24 million people will lose their insurance, Medicaid and Medicare will be dramatically cut, and key protections like maternity care and drug prescriptions will be gutted by insurance companies. Together, TrumpCare will provide less coverage, fewer protections, and higher costs.

TrumpCare is a direct assault on President Donald J. Trump's promise to the American people. This bill will lead to higher premiums, fewer benefits, and more people uninsured.   Physician groups and hospital associations all oppose this bill and I urge my colleagues to vote no.

Today is a victory for the American people and all 24 million Americans who would have lost their health care if TrumpCare was signed into law. If the House Republican Majority was serious about keeping children healthy, they wouldn't use the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) as a bargaining tool to further sabotage the Affordable Care Act.  Since its creation 20 years ago, CHIP has always been approved by Congress on a bipartisan basis. The notion that we have to cut important programs and take insurance away from one group to give it to another is a false choice. I hope my colleagues in the Senate can work on a bipartisan compromise that will provide full and stable funding for these programs for five years in a way that does not reduce care or kick other people off their health insurance.

The decision from the Trump Administration to end Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for thousands of Nicaraguans living legally in the United States is not how you attempt to fix our immigration system.   There are mothers and fathers who have lived in the United States for two decades, gave birth to American-born children, and are law-abiding people who contribute to our economy. The deportation of TPS recipients would cost taxpayers $3.1 billion dollars and more than $967 million turnover cost for businesses. I urge the President to reconsider his action and extend TPS to give the participating countries more time to rebuild and recover.

The Domestic Maritime Centers of Excellence Act was introduced in May 2017 and was successfully added as an amendment to the NDAA during the committee markup. It will authorize the U.S. Maritime Administration to designate and provide assistance to certain community colleges and workforce training centers as “centers of excellence” that provide valuable skills in the maritime sector. The provision, Section 3507, will advance the capabilities of two-year community and technical colleges to expand the talent pipeline for domestic maritime industry jobs at the Port of Houston and other ports around the country.   The NDAA is expected to be quickly passed by the Senate and sent to the desk of the President to be signed into law.

I spoke on the House floor moments ago to oppose the #GOPTaxScam.  Once again, the @HouseGOP is rushing to pass a bill without a full assessment from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office of what it will do to our economy, children, and grandchildren. Tax cuts for the rich and corporations will hurt the economy and cost jobs by causing big cuts to education, healthcare, infrastructure, and other investments.   Trickle-down economics does not equal growth. It didn't work in 1986 and it surely won't work today.

It’s a shame that the House Republican majority rushed to pass a tax bill knowing it will increase taxes for middle-class Americans and deliver a huge tax cut to the wealthiest households and multinational corporations.   To pay for the tax cuts for the rich, the Republican majority plans to eliminate tax deductions that millions of middle-class families claim annually and make deep cuts to Medicare and Medicaid, which will lead to 36 million middle-class families paying more.  The last time America’s tax system was overhauled was in 1986, but it was done on a bipartisan basis and took at least a year before there was a final vote. The Republicans this time around decided to jam a strictly partisan bill and shutout Democrats from the entire process.

I want to thank every constituent who has called, emailed, or sent a letter to our office to oppose Federal Communications Commission Chairman Pai’s proposal. I, too, oppose the FCC’s awful plan. Net neutrality is important for several reasons: It protects Internet freedom, drives innovation, and protects American consumers.   There could be adverse consequences for American consumers and our economy if the current net neutrality rules are eliminated, which protect consumers from having content of their choice being blocked or slowed down. These protections have allowed a whole new sector of our economy to develop and create thousands of jobs in Texas and throughout our country.   There must be rules in place that protect the Internet for small businesses, consumers, and innovators from potential abuse. This is why I oppose this proposal and urge FCC Chairman Pai to reverse his proposal.
